content: The "Bailout Prevention Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title. Discounts are provided for individuals, partnerships, and corporations. The "Bailout Prevention Act of 2017" allows discounts for individuals, partnerships, and corporations. Section 13(3)(B) of the Federal Reserve Act is amended to establish procedures prohibiting borrowing from programs by insolvent borrowers. Borrowers must be certified as not insolvent by the Board and Federal banking regulators before accessing emergency lending programs. Solvency is determined by comparing the fair value of assets to liabilities over the last 4 months. The "Bailout Prevention Act of 2017" amends Section 13(3)(B) of the Federal Reserve Act to establish procedures prohibiting borrowing from programs by insolvent borrowers. Insolvency is determined by comparing the fair value of the borrower's liabilities, with adjustments for temporary illiquidity, and includes being in bankruptcy or insolvency proceedings. The "Bailout Prevention Act of 2017" amends Section 13(3)(B) of the Federal Reserve Act to establish procedures prohibiting borrowing from programs by insolvent borrowers. If the Board or banking regulator certifies solvency, a detailed public statement must be issued. A program or facility must have broad-based eligibility with at least 5 eligible companies participating significantly. The "Bailout Prevention Act of 2017" establishes procedures to prevent borrowing from programs by insolvent borrowers, requiring certification of solvency and a detailed public statement. Eligible companies must have broad-based eligibility with at least 5 participants. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require emergency lending at an interest rate 500 basis points higher than the Treasury's borrowing cost. The Board can create emergency lending programs that do not meet certain requirements but must report within 3 days. The Board must report to Congress within 3 days if unable to comply with requirements for emergency lending programs, which will terminate in 30 days unless approved by a joint resolution. The emergency lending programs must be repaid in full within 30 days of termination, as specified in a joint resolution introduced to Congress within 3 days of receiving the report from the Board. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System creates a program or facility that Congress must approve within a specified timeframe. The Speaker of the House must notify members to convene within two days after receiving a report under subsection (a)(3). After receiving a report, any House committee must report a joint resolution within 5 days. Failure to do so results in discharge from consideration. Once reported or discharged, the joint resolution can be considered by Congress within 6 days. The House receives a report on a joint resolution and can proceed to consider it without debate or reconsideration. All points of order are waived, and the resolution is considered as read. The joint resolution shall be considered without debate or reconsideration. The Senate must convene within two days of receiving a report if adjourned for more than two days. Upon introduction in the Senate, the joint resolution is immediately placed on the calendar. It is in order to move to proceed to the consideration of the joint resolution within a specific timeframe, with all points of order waived and the motion not debatable. The motion to proceed to the consideration of the joint resolution is not debatable and not subject to a motion to postpone. Debate on the resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Amendments, motions to postpone, or motions to proceed are in order but not debatable. The vote on passage of a joint resolution shall occur immediately following the debate, with appeals on rules decisions decided without debate. If one House receives a joint resolution from the other House before passing its own, certain procedures apply. If one House fails to introduce or consider a joint resolution, the resolution from the other House will receive expedited floor procedures. Expedited floor procedures apply if the Senate receives a companion measure from the House after passing a joint resolution. If the President vetoes the resolution, the time between the veto and Congress receiving the message is not counted towards the 30-day period for debate. The subclause and subclauses enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the Senate and House of Representatives, applicable only with respect to the procedure for a joint resolution, supersedes other rules to the extent of inconsistency, recognizing the constitutional right of either House to change the rules related to the procedure. The rules regarding the procedure of the House can be changed at any time to the same extent as any other rule of the House. SEC. 4. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION RELATED TO CREDIT FACILITIES.
